body.p: Our managed DNS service, based on the OpenStack Designate project, is engineered to help you create, publish, and manage your DNS zones and records securely and efficiently for either a public or private DNS server network.

ul.li: installation must be completed. You must know the location of its keystone.osrc file, which contains configuration information.
You must know the NTP server and DNS server IP addresses.
Credentials of the User and Tenant where the service is to be deployed ("Target Credentials")
"openrc" credentials file for the Target user and project
The v2 CLI must be installed on all nodes due to client differences.

The SVC network correctly configured within . See the Creating the HPE Helion Development Platform Service Net for information on setting up the network. The DNSaaS installation requires that the svc network be named "SVC". User defined names for the SVC network are currently not supported.
A SSH public and private keypair.

li.note: Selecting a flavor larger than m1.medium for the Deployer or Control Plane nodes fails due to a failure to re-size LVM. The recommended flavors for the Deployer and Control Plane nodes are m1.small or m1.medium.

section.title: Creating the Prerequisite Credentials
section.p: Target credentials are the credentials of the user and project where the service is to be deployed. Target credentials include a project name and a username. Service credentials can only be created after the Target credentials have been successfully created.

ol.li: SSH to the deployer.
Source the keystone.osrc file. $ source keystone.osrc

Create the DNSaaS project. Make a note of the ID field value.$ openstack project create dnsaas +-------------+----------------------------------+ | Field | Value | +-------------+----------------------------------+ | description | | | domain_id | default | | enabled | True | | id | a6c8339e816c4f4fb9118b31e2e101ad |
[ OUPUT TRIMMED]
Create a dnsaas user. $ openstack user create dnsaas --password password --email dnsaas@example.com --project dnsaas
Add roles to the dnsaas user. $ openstack role add --project dnsaas --user dnsaas _member_ $ openstack role add --project dnsaas --user dnsaas admin
You can view the roles with role list. $ openstack role list

section.title: DNSaaS User and Project Credentials
section.p: Prepare the credentials files for the DNSaaS user and project.
section.codeblock: $ cat <<EOF > dnsaas.osrc unset OS_DOMAIN_NAME export OS_IDENTITY_API_VERSION=3 export OS_AUTH_VERSION=3 export OS_PROJECT_DOMAIN_NAME=Default export OS_USER_DOMAIN_NAME=Default export OS_ENDPOINT_TYPE=internalURL export OS_INTERFACE=internal export OS_CACERT=/etc/ssl/certs/ca-certificates.crt export OS_PROJECT_NAME=dnsaas export OS_USERNAME=dnsaas export OS_PASSWORD=password export OS_AUTH_URL=http://192.168.245.5:35357/v3 EOF

section.title: Provision DNSaaS Images
section.p: You will need to select which way you would like to provision the images for DNSaaS into your Helion instance.

ol.li:
Automatic - Using the Images and Updates extension
Login into Horizon using the DNSaaS credentials created above.
Navigate to the Update and Extensions panel.
Click Download and Install It's best to do this from within the tenant you plan on deploying DNSaaS with, as the images are uploaded as private to the tenant you're logged in with during the time of publication.
Now once the state goes into Installed, the images will be pre-uploaded into Glance. The Deployer tarball is uploaded to a swift container called dnsaas-deployer for you to download.
To download the tarball from swift you can use the Swift client, type the following command: swift download dnsaas-deployer

Manual - Download and provision images to your cloud.
Navigate to the HPE Helion Download Network (HDN) and log in. If necessary, create an account first. Select the required package and Download the DNSaaS Installer csu file to your local directory.
Unzip the csu to extract the deployer and cloud image tar ball. On Windows, for example, things may be pigeonholed into .zip is Zip and .csu is Unknown. So renaming the .csu file to .zip will possibly make it work with the unzip utility of choice.

sectiondiv.b: Preparing to boot the Deployer VM
sectiondiv.p: You must publish the DNSaaS Cloud Image to the target project/tenant before proceeding to the next step.

ol.li: Update your environment. $ source dnsaas.osrc

Identify the SVC network ID. Make a note of the SVC ID value.$ neutron net-show SVC +---------------------------+--------------------------------------+ | Field | Value | +---------------------------+--------------------------------------+ | admin_state_up | True | | id | <service ID Value> |
[ OUTPUT TRIMMED ]
Upload the SSH keypair. $ nova keypair-add --pub-key dns_shared.pub dns-shared
You can view the keypair information with keypair-show. $ nova keypair-show dns-shared
Ensure the default security group is correctly configured. You will need the ID value from the "create the project" step.$ neutron security-group-list --tenant-id <value of the owner parameter>

Create security group rules. $ neutron security-group-rule-create \ --tenant-id <value of the owner parameter from OpenStack Project Create command> \ --protocol TCP \ --remote-ip-prefix 0.0.0.0/0 \ --port-range-min 22 \ --port-range-max 22 \ <default security group rule ID>
$ neutron security-group-rule-create \ --tenant-id <value of the project ID parameter from the OpenStack Project Create command> \ --protocol TCP \ --remote-ip-prefix 0.0.0.0/0 \ --port-range-min 79 \ --port-range-max 79 \ <default security group rule ID>
You can view the security groups with security_group_list $ neutron security-group-list --tenant-id <project ID>

sectiondiv.b: Booting the Deployer VM and Uploading the Deployer Tarball

ol.li: Boot the Deployer VM. $ nova boot --poll \ --nic net-id=<SVC ID Value> \ # SVC Network ID --image <DNS Cloud Image ID>\ # DNSaaS Cloud Image ID --key-name dns-shared \ # Keypair Name --flavor m1.small \ dnsaas-deployer
Display the dnsaas-deployer. Make a note of the SVC-NET IP Address.$ nova show dnsaas-deployer
Copy the dnsaas image. $ scp -i dns_shared dnsaas-2.0.0-b.1-20151005T183829Z.tgz stack@<SVC-NET IP Address>:~

sectiondiv.b: Login and Initialize the Deployer VM

ol.li:
Login to the deployer. $ ssh -i dns_shared stack@<SVC-NET IP Address> You will need to extract the dnsaas tar file and execute the dns-init.bash script. $ tar xf dnsaas-2.0.0-b.1-20151005T183829Z.tar $ cd dnsaas-2.0.0-b.1/ $ ./dnsaas-init.bash [ OUTPUT TRIMMED ]
+ ssh-keygen -q -t rsa -f id_rsa Enter passphrase (empty for no passphrase): Enter same passphrase again:
[ OUTPUT TRIMMED ]
# Do not continue with the installation steps that appear here # Ignore this next line. To continue installation copy your cloud layout to: /home/stack/helion/my_cloud/definition

section.title: Prepare the Deployment

sectiondiv.p: DNSaaS has several example models that can be deployed. In the following example, the powerdns example deployment model is used.
sectiondiv.note: The cp command must be used exactly as shown - including the /* on the end of the example model path.
sectiondiv.codeblock: $ cd ~/helion $ cp -r examples/powerdns/* my_cloud/definition/ $ git add -A $ git commit -a -m "Add DNSaaS Example Model"

ol.li: You will need to change directories to the my_cloud/definition directory and run nano to configure your DNS and NTP servers. $ cd my_cloud/definition/ $ nano cloudConfig.yml
Run the ansible-playbook on the deployer.cd ~/scratch/ansible/next/hos/ansible ansible-playbook -i hosts/verb_hosts platform-pass-through.yml -e pass_through_key=""

Copy the contents of the platform-pass-through.yml file as follows:
Copy from: <HOS deployer>:~/platform-pass-through.yml
Copy to: <DNSaaS deployer>: ~/helion/my_cloud/definition/data/pass-through/platform-pass-through/platform-pass-through.yml
Commit the changes to git. $ git add -A $ git commit -a -m "Save DNSaaS config file changes."

Run the Pre-Installation Playbook
Copy the ~/dnsaas.osrc file from the deployer. At the end of each playbook, ensure both "unreachable" and "failed" are zero. $ source ~/dnsaas.osrc $ cd ~/helion/hos/ansible/ $ ansible-playbook -i hosts/localhost hlm-pre-install.yml

sectiondiv.p: If you want to install a self-signed certificate that meets the needs of and HPE Helion Development Platform, follow the steps outlined in the FQDN-based Certificate section. If you want to create an IP-address Certificate follow the steps in the IP-Address Certificate section.
You will need a real or fictional domain name e.g. "your.domain.com" and it must match across the next 3 steps.

ol.li: Create a Certificate Signing Request (CSR) with a defined subject. cd ~ openssl req -nodes -days 365 -newkey rsa:2048 -keyout my-public-cert.key -out my-public-cert.csr -text \ -subj '/C=US/O=Helion Test Certificate/CN=your.domain.com/emailAddress=test@example.org/'

Create a file containing v3 extensions Ensure that the DNS entry matches any CN entry above and provide your IP address. The IP address is what is used by HPE Helion Development Platform and the DNS is used by . Update the "subjectAltName" value with the domain name subjectAltName=DNS:your.domain.com $ cat > v3_ext.cnf << EOF [ v3_req ] subjectAltName=DNS:your.domain.com EOF
Self-sign your certificate. $ openssl x509 -extfile v3_ext.cnf -extensions v3_req -in my-public-cert.csr -signkey my-public-cert.key -req -out my-public-cert.crt -text

Installing the Certificate. If you are using a FQDN - Create or obtain a certificate to match the domain name you are going to use.
Join the private and public keys into "my-cert-file" at the required location. $ cat my-public-cert.key my-public-cert.crt > ~/helion/my_cloud/config/tls/certs/my-public-cert
Edit network_groups.yml, locate a line containing name: extlb. Add the following lines at the same indentation level as name: extlb external-name: your.domain.name cert-file: my-public-cert
Rename the "components" section of the extlb for a "tls-components" section, activating TLS on all external components. $ nano ~/helion/my_cloud/definition/data/network_groups.yml
Add changes to git. $ git add hos/ansible/roles/tls-frontend/files/my-public-cert my_cloud/definition/data/network_groups.yml $ git diff ^HEAD my_cloud/definition/data/network_groups.yml # --- Output example --- - hostname: false hostname-suffix: ext load-balancers: - - components: + - tls-components: - default external-ip: 172.31.0.2 name: extlb + cert-file: my-public-cert + external-name: your.domain.name provider: ip-cluster roles: - public
$ git commit -m "Configure SSL certificate"
Commit changes to git. $ git commit -m "Configure SSL certificate"
Identify the external IP Address. grep 'external-ip' ~/helion/my_cloud/definition/data/network_groups.yml

Create a Certificate Signing Request (CSR) with a defined subject. stack@dnsaas-deployer:~$ cd ~ stack@dnsaas-deployer:~$ openssl req -nodes -days 365 -newkey rsa:2048 -keyout my-public-cert.key -out my-public-cert.csr -text \ -subj '/C=US/O=Helion Test Certificate/CN=<EXTERNAL_IP_ADDRESS>/emailAddress=test@example.org/'

Create a file containing v3 extensions Ensure that the DNS entry matches any CN entr above and provide your IP address. The IP address must be the same in DNS: and IP: The IP address is what is used by HPE Helion Development Platform and the DNS is used by . stack@dnsaas-deployer:~$ cat > v3_ext.cnf << EOF [ v3_req ] subjectAltName=DNS:<EXTERNAL_IP_ADDRESS>, IP:<EXTERNAL_IP_ADDRESS> [ alt_names ] IP.1 = <EXTERNAL_IP_ADDRESS> DNS.1 = <EXTERNAL_IP_ADDRESS> EOF
Self-sign your certificate. $ openssl x509 -extfile v3_ext.cnf -extensions v3_req -in my-public-cert.csr -signkey my-public-cert.key -req -out my-public-cert.crt -text

Installing the Certificate.
Join the private and public keys into "my-cert-file" at the required location. $ cat my-public-cert.key my-public-cert.crt > ~/helion/my_cloud/config/tls/certs/my-public-cert
Edit network_groups.yml, locate a line containing name: extlb. Add the following lines at the same indentation level as name: extlb cert-file: my-public-cert
Rename the "components" section of the extlb for a "tls-components" section, activating TLS on all external components. $ nano ~/helion/my_cloud/definition/data/network_groups.yml
Add changes to git. $ git add hos/ansible/roles/tls-frontend/files/my-public-cert my_cloud/definition/data/network_groups.yml $ git diff ^HEAD my_cloud/definition/data/network_groups.yml # --- Output example --- - hostname: false hostname-suffix: ext load-balancers: - - components: + - tls-components: - default external-ip: 172.31.0.2 name: extlb + cert-file: my-public-cert provider: ip-cluster roles: - public
Commit changes to git. $ git commit -m "Configure SSL certificate"

Add your changes to Git. $ cd ~/helion $ git add -A $ git commit -a -m "Configured Deployment Model" $ git status Make sure that there are no other files which are not committed to the Git repository. If there are, begin troubleshooting.

sectiondiv.note: When asked for a encryption key, simply leave the value blank, pressing enter 4 times to proceed.

sectiondiv.p: Once this is complete, all in-cloud infrastructure (VMs, Networks, Routers, Floating IPs etc) will have been created.
sectiondiv.note: This step takes approximately 15 minutes to run.
sectiondiv.codeblock:
$ cd ~/scratch/ansible/next/hos/ansible
# Choose between single or multiple control plane. You only need to execute one or the other, do not run both.
# a) Multiple control plane nodes $ ansible-playbook -i hosts/localhost hlm-boot-infra.yml
# b) Single control plane $ ansible-playbook -i hosts/localhost hlm-boot-infra.yml -e neutron_router_ha=False

This step take approximately 15 to 20 minutes to complete.

sectiondiv.p: To direct DNS traffic towards the DNSaaS managed nameservers, you must first identify the Floating IPs associated with each server. Each of the name servers (e.g. dnsaas-cp-ns0001-mgmt) will have two IPs listed for the DNSAAS_NET_EXT network, the second IP address (e.g. 172.31.0.10) is the Floating IP. It is recommended that you gather all IPs for the nameservers and before proceeding to the next step.

ol.li: Source the dnsaas.osrc file. $ source dnsaas.osrc

sectiondiv.p: For each nameserver, choose a public FQDN. For example "ns1.mycloud.com", and create the server entry in Designate.

ol.li: Source the dnsaas.osrc file. $ source dnsaas.osrc

p.b: Create the A records for each Name Server

sectiondiv.p: The following table of data is required - the table here is based on the example outputs above.

NS Hostname NS FQDN NS Floating IP
dnsaas-cp-ns0001-mgmt ns1.mycloud.com 169.254.2.23
dnsaas-cp-ns0002-mgmt ns2.mycloud.com 169.254.2.24
dnsaas-cp-ns0003-mgmt ns3.mycloud.com 169.254.2.2
For each name chosen, provide the external service the name and Floating IP address for each nameserver, or create the matching zone and records within Designate.
